Name: CPIA business regulatory environment rating (1=low to 6=high)
Notes: Business regulatory environment assesses the extent to which the legal, regulatory, and policy environments help or hinder private businesses in investing, creating jobs, and becoming more productive.

Name: CPIA debt policy rating (1=low to 6=high)
Notes: Debt policy assesses whether the debt management strategy is conducive to minimizing budgetary risks and ensuring long-term debt sustainability.

Name: CPIA economic management cluster average (1=low to 6=high)
Notes: The economic management cluster includes macroeconomic management, fiscal policy, and debt policy.

Name: CPIA policy and institutions for environmental sustainability rating (1=low to 6=high)
Notes: Policy and institutions for environmental sustainability assess the extent to which environmental policies foster the protection and sustainable use of natural resources and the management of pollution.

Name: CPIA quality of budgetary and financial management rating (1=low to 6=high)
Notes: Quality of budgetary and financial management assesses the extent to which there is a comprehensive and credible budget linked to policy priorities, effective financial management systems, and timely and accurate accounting and fiscal reporting, including timely and audited public accounts.

Name: CPIA financial sector rating (1=low to 6=high)
Notes: Financial sector assesses the structure of the financial sector and the policies and regulations that affect it.

Name: CPIA fiscal policy rating (1=low to 6=high)
Notes: Fiscal policy assesses the short- and medium-term sustainability of fiscal policy (taking into account monetary and exchange rate policy and the sustainability of the public debt) and its impact on growth.

Name: CPIA gender equality rating (1=low to 6=high)
Notes: Gender equality assesses the extent to which the country has installed institutions and programs to enforce laws and policies that promote equal access for men and women in education, health, the economy, and protection under law.

Name: CPIA building human resources rating (1=low to 6=high)
Notes: Building human resources assesses the national policies and public and private sector service delivery that affect the access to and quality of health and education services, including prevention and treatment of HIV/AIDS, tuberculosis, and malaria.

Name: IDA resource allocation index (1=low to 6=high)
Notes: IDA Resource Allocation Index is obtained by calculating the average score for each cluster and then by averaging those scores. For each of 16 criteria countries are rated on a scale of 1 (low) to 6 (high).

Name: CPIA macroeconomic management rating (1=low to 6=high)
Notes: Macroeconomic management assesses the monetary, exchange rate, and aggregate demand policy framework.

Name: CPIA quality of public administration rating (1=low to 6=high)
Notes: Quality of public administration assesses the extent to which civilian central government staff is structured to design and implement government policy and deliver services effectively.

Name: CPIA equity of public resource use rating (1=low to 6=high)
Notes: Equity of public resource use assesses the extent to which the pattern of public expenditures and revenue collection affects the poor and is consistent with national poverty reduction priorities.

Name: CPIA property rights and rule-based governance rating (1=low to 6=high)
Notes: Property rights and rule-based governance assess the extent to which private economic activity is facilitated by an effective legal system and rule-based governance structure in which property and contract rights are reliably respected and enforced.

Name: CPIA social protection rating (1=low to 6=high)
Notes: Social protection and labor assess government policies in social protection and labor market regulations that reduce the risk of becoming poor, assist those who are poor to better manage further risks, and ensure a minimal level of welfare to all people.

Name: CPIA public sector management and institutions cluster average (1=low to 6=high)
Notes: The public sector management and institutions cluster includes property rights and rule-based governance, quality of budgetary and financial management, efficiency of revenue mobilization, quality of public administration, and transparency, accountability, and corruption in the public sector.

Name: CPIA efficiency of revenue mobilization rating (1=low to 6=high)
Notes: Efficiency of revenue mobilization assesses the overall pattern of revenue mobilization--not only the de facto tax structure, but also revenue from all sources as actually collected.

Name: CPIA policies for social inclusion/equity cluster average (1=low to 6=high)
Notes: The policies for social inclusion and equity cluster includes gender equality, equity of public resource use, building human resources, social protection and labor, and policies and institutions for environmental sustainability.

Name: CPIA structural policies cluster average (1=low to 6=high)
Notes: The structural policies cluster includes trade, financial sector, and business regulatory environment.

Name: CPIA trade rating (1=low to 6=high)
Notes: Trade assesses how the policy framework fosters trade in goods.

Name: CPIA transparency, accountability, and corruption in the public sector rating (1=low to 6=high)
Notes: Transparency, accountability, and corruption in the public sector assess the extent to which the executive can be held accountable for its use of funds and for the results of its actions by the electorate and by the legislature and judiciary, and the extent to which public employees within the executive are required to account for administrative decisions, use of resources, and results obtained. The three main dimensions assessed here are the accountability of the executive to oversight institutions and of public employees for their performance, access of civil society to information on public affairs, and state capture by narrow vested interests.

Name: Bank accounts per 1,000 adults
Notes: For each country calculated as: 1,000*reported number of depositors/adult population in the reporting country.

Name: Bank branches per 100,000 adults
Notes: For each country calculated as: 100,000*reported number of depositors/adult population in the reporting country.

Name: Firms with a bank loan or line of credit (%)
Notes: Percentage of firms in the formal sector with a line of credit or a loan from a formal financial institution, such as a bank, credit union, microfinance institution, or cooperative.

Name: Small firms with a bank loan or line of credit (%)
Notes: Percentage of small firms (5-19 workers) in the formal sector with a line of credit or a loan from a (formal) financial institution, such as a bank, credit union, microfinance institution, or cooperative.

Name: Account at a formal financial institution (% age 15+)
Notes: The percentage of respondents with an account (self or together with someone else) at a bank, credit union, another financial institution (e.g., cooperative, microfinance institution), or the post office (if applicable) including respondents who reported having a debit card (% age 15+).

Name: Saved at a financial institution in the past year (% age 15+)
Notes: The percentage of respondents who report saving or setting aside any money by using an account at a formal financial institution such as a bank, credit union, microfinance institution, or cooperative in the past 12 months (% age 15+).

Name: Loan from a financial institution in the past year (% age 15+)
Notes: The percentage of respondents who report borrowing any money from a bank, credit union, microfinance institution, or another financial institution such as a cooperative in the past 12 months (% age 15+).

Name: Account used for business purposes (% age 15+)
Notes: The percentage of respondents who report using their accounts at a formal financial institution for business purposes only or for both business purposes and personal transactions (% age 15+).

Name: Account used to receive government payments (% age 15+)
Notes: The percentage of respondents who report using their accounts at a formal financial institution to receive money or payments from the government in the past 12 months (% age 15+).

Name: Account used to receive remittances (% age 15+)
Notes: The percentage of respondents who report using their accounts at a formal financial institution to receive money from family members living elsewhere in the past 12 months (% age 15+).

Name: Account used to receive wages (% age 15+)
Notes: The percentage of respondents who report using their accounts at a formal financial institution to receive money or payments for work or from selling goods in the past 12 months (% age 15+).

Name: Saved any money in the past year (% age 15+)
Notes: The percentage of respondents who report saving or setting aside any money in the past 12 months (% age 15+).

Name: Saved using a savings club in the past year (% age 15+)
Notes: The percentage of respondents who report saving or setting aside any money by using an informal savings club or a person outside the family in the past 12 months (% age 15+).

Name: Loan in the past year (% age 15+)
Notes: The percentage of respondents who borrowed any money in the past 12 months from any of the following sources: a formal financial institution, a store by using installment credit, family or friends, employer, or another private lender (% age 15+). (Note that getting a loan does not necessarily require having an account.)

Name: Loan from a private lender in the past year (% age 15+)
Notes: The percentage of respondents who report borrowing any money from a private lender in the past 12 months (% age 15+).

Name: Loan from an employer in the past year (% age 15+)
Notes: The percentage of respondents who report borrowing any money from an employer in the past 12 months (% age 15+).

Name: Loan through store credit in the past year (% age 15+)
Notes: The percentage of respondents who borrowed any money in the past 12 months from a store by using installment credit or buying on credit (% age 15+).

Name: Loan from family or friends in the past year (% age 15+)
Notes: The percentage of respondents who report borrowing any money from family or friends in the past 12 months (% age 15+).

Name: Checks used to make payments (% age 15+)
Notes: The percentage of respondents who used checks in the past 12 months to make payments on bills or to buy things using money from their accounts (% age 15+).

Name: Credit card (% age 15+)
Notes: The percentage of respondents with a credit card (% age 15+).

Name: Debit card (% age 15+)
Notes: The percentage of respondents with a debit card (% age 15+).

Name: Electronic payments used to make payments (% age 15+)
Notes: The percentage of respondents who used electronic payments (payments that one makes or that are made automatically including wire transfers or payments made online) in the past 12 months to make payments on bills or to buy things using money from their accounts (% age 15+).

Name: Mobile phone used to pay bills (% age 15+)
Notes: The percentage of respondents who report using a mobile phone to pay bills in the past 12 months (% age 15+).

Name: Mobile phone used to send money (% age 15+)
Notes: The percentage of respondents who report using a mobile phone to send money in the past 12 months (% age 15+).

Name: ATMs per 100,000 adults
Notes: For each country calculated as: 100,000*Number of ATMs/adult population in the reporting country.

Name: Depositing/withdrawing at least once in a typical month (% age 15+)
Notes: Adults depositing/withdrawing at least once in a typical month (% age 15+). It is calculated as follows: (100 - "0 deposits/withdrawals in typical month (% with an account,  age 15+)" ) * ("Account at a formal financial institution (% age 15+)") / 100.  "0 deposits/withdrawals in typical month (% with an account,  age 15+)" denotes the percentage of respondents with an account at a formal financial institution who report making zero deposits into or zero withdrawals from their personal account(s) in a typical month (also called “inactive account”). This includes cash or electronic deposits, or any time money is put into or removed from account(s) by self or others (% age 15+, with an account). "Account at a formal financial institution (% age 15+)" denotes the percentage of respondents with an account (self or together with someone else) at a bank, credit union, another financial institution (e.g., cooperative, microfinance institution), or the post office (if applicable) including respondents who reported having a debit card (% age 15+).

Name: Firms with a checking or savings account (%)
Notes: Percentage of firms with a checking or savings account.

Name: Firms using banks to finance investments (%)
Notes: Percentage of firms using banks to finance purchases of fixed assets.

Name: Firms using banks to finance working capital (%)
Notes: Percentage of firms using bank loans to finance working capital.

Name: Loans requiring collateral (%)
Notes: Percentage of loans where a formal financial institution requires collateral in order to provide the financing.

Name: Value of collateral needed for a loan (% of the loan amount)
Notes: Value of collateral needed by a formal financial institution for a loan or line of credit as a percentage of the loan value or the value of the line of credit.

Name: Firms not needing a loan (%)
Notes: Percent of firms that did not apply for a loan in the last fiscal year because they did not need a loan. The denominator is the sum of all firms who applied and did not apply for a loan. The numerator is the number of firms who did not apply for a loan and also stated that they did not need a loan.

Name: Firms whose recent loan application was rejected (%)
Notes: Percent of firms whose most recent loan application was rejected by a formal financial institution.

Name: Investments financed by banks (%)
Notes: Estimated proportion of purchases of fixed assets that was financed from bank loans.

Name: Working capital financed by banks (%)
Notes: Proportion of the working capital that was financed by bank loans.

Name: Firms identifying access to finance as a major constraint (%)
Notes: Percentage of firms identifying access/cost of finance as a "major" or "very severe" obstacle.

Name: Value traded excluding top 10 traded companies to total value traded (%)
Notes: Value of all traded shares outside of the top ten largest traded companies as a share of total value of all traded shares in a stock market exchange. WFE provides data on the exchange level. This variable is aggregated up to the country level by taking a simple average over exchanges.

Name: Market capitalization excluding top 10 companies to total market capitalization (%)
Notes: Value of listed shares outside of the top ten largest companies to total value of all listed shares.

Name: Nonfinancial corporate bonds to total bonds and notes outstanding (%)
Notes: Total amount of domestic nonfinancial corporate bonds and notes outstanding (BIS Table 16B) to total amount of domestic bonds and notes outstanding, both corporate and noncorporate (BIS Table 16A).

Name: Private credit by deposit money banks to GDP (%)
Notes: Private credit by deposit money banks and other financial institutions to GDP, calculated using the following deflation method:  {(0.5)*[Ft/P_et + Ft-1/P_et-1]}/[GDPt/P_at] where F is credit to the private sector, P_e is end-of period CPI, and P_a is average annual CPI. Raw data are from the electronic version of the IMF’s International Financial Statistics. Private credit by deposit money banks (IFS line 22d); GDP in local currency (IFS line 99B..ZF or, if not available, line 99B.CZF); end-of period CPI (IFS line 64M..ZF or, if not available, 64Q..ZF); and average annual CPI is calculated using the monthly CPI values (IFS line 64M..ZF).

Name: Deposit money banks'' assets to GDP (%)
Notes: Claims on domestic real nonfinancial sector by deposit money banks as a share of GDP, calculated using the following deflation method:  {(0.5)*[Ft/P_et + Ft-1/P_et-1]}/[GDPt/P_at] where F is deposit money bank claims, P_e is end-of period CPI, and P_a is average annual CPI. Raw data are from the electronic version of the IMF’s International Financial Statistics. Deposit money bank assets (IFS lines 22, a-d); GDP in local currency (IFS line 99B..ZF or, if not available, line 99B.CZF); end-of period CPI (IFS line 64M..ZF or, if not available, 64Q..ZF); and average annual CPI is calculated using the monthly CPI values (IFS line 64M..ZF).

Name: Nonbank financial institutions’ assets to GDP (%)
Notes: Claims on domestic real nonfinancial sector by other financial institutions as a share of GDP, calculated using the following deflation method: {(0.5)*[Ft/P_et + Ft-1/P_et-1]}/[GDPt/P_at]  where F is other financial institutions' claims, P_e is end-of period CPI, and P_a is average annual CPI. Raw data are from the electronic version of the IMF’s International Financial Statistics. Nonbank financial institutions assets (IFS lines 42, a-d, h, and s); GDP in local currency (IFS line 99B..ZF or, if not available, line 99B.CZF); end-of period CPI (IFS line 64M..ZF or, if not available, 64Q..ZF); and average annual CPI is calculated using the monthly CPI values (IFS line 64M..ZF).

Name: Deposit money bank assets to deposit money bank assets and central bank assets (%)
Notes: Raw data are from the electronic version of the IMF's International Financial Statistics (IFS lines 12 and 22, a-d).

Name: Liquid liabilities to GDP (%)
Notes: Ratio of liquid liabilities to GDP, calculated using the following deflation method: {(0.5)*[Ft/P_et + Ft-1/P_et-1]}/[GDPt/P_at] where F is liquid liabilities, P_e is end-of period CPI, and P_a is average annual CPI. Raw data are from the electronic version of the IMF's International Financial Statistics. Liquid liabilities (IFS lines 55L or, if not available, line 35L); GDP in local currency (IFS line 99B..ZF or, if not available, line 99B.CZF); end-of period CPI (IFS line 64M..ZF or, if not available, 64Q..ZF); and average annual CPI is calculated using the monthly CPI values (IFS line 64M..ZF) For Eurocurrency  area countries liquid liabilities are estimated by summing IFS items 34A, 34B and 35.

Name: Central bank assets to GDP (%)
Notes: Claims on domestic real nonfinancial sector by the Central Bank as a share of GDP, calculated using the following deflation method:  {(0.5)*[Ft/P_et + Ft-1/P_et-1]}/[GDPt/P_at] where F is Central Bank claims, P_e is end-of period CPI, and P_a is average annual CPI. Raw data are from the electronic version of the IMF's International Financial Statistics. Central Bank claims (IFS lines 12, a-d); GDP in local currency (IFS line 99B..ZF or, if not available, line 99B.CZF); end-of period CPI (IFS line 64M..ZF or, if not available, 64Q..ZF); and average annual CPI is calculated using the monthly CPI values (IFS line 64M..ZF).

Name: Mutual fund assets to GDP (%)
Notes: Data taken from a variety of sources such as Investment Company Institute and national sources.

Name: Financial system deposits to GDP (%)
Notes: Demand, time and saving deposits in deposit money banks and other financial institutions as a share of GDP, calculated using the following deflation method:  {(0.5)*[Ft/P_et + Ft-1/P_et-1]}/[GDPt/P_at] where F is demand and time and saving deposits, P_e is end-of period CPI, and P_a is average annual CPI. Raw data are from the electronic version of the IMF’s International Financial Statistics. Financial system deposits (IFS lines 24, 25, 44, and 45); GDP in local currency (IFS line 99B..ZF or, if not available, line 99B.CZF); end-of period CPI (IFS line 64M..ZF or, if not available, 64Q..ZF); and average annual CPI is calculated using the monthly CPI values (IFS line 64M..ZF).

Name: Life insurance premium volume to GDP (%)
Notes: Premium data is taken from various issues of Sigma reports (Swiss Re). Data on GDP in US dollars is from the electronic version of the World Development Indicators.

Name: Non-life insurance premium volume to GDP (%)
Notes: Premium data is taken from various issues of Sigma reports (Swiss Re). Data on GDP in US dollars is from the electronic version of the World Development Indicators.

Name: Insurance company assets to GDP (%)
Notes: Data taken from a variety of sources such as AXCO and national sources.

Literacy rate, youth total (% of people ages 15-24)
Notes: The number of persons aged 15 to 24 years who can both read and write with understanding a short simple statement on their everyday life, divided by the population in that age group. Generally, ‘literacy’ also encompasses ‘numeracy’, the ability to make simple arithmetic calculations. For further country-specific definition details please refer to the source of information, the UNESCO Institute for Statistics (UIS): www.uis.unesco.org

Name: School enrolment, preprimary, national source (% gross)
Notes: Pre-Primary Gross Enrolment Rate (GER): The number of pupils enrolled in pre-primary school, regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the population in the theoretical age group in pre-primary school. The purpose of this indicator is to measure the general level of participation of children in Early Childhood Education (ECE) programs. Country-specific definition, method and targets are determined by countries themselves.

Name: Gross intake ratio in grade 1, total, national source (% of relevant age group)
Notes: Gross intake ratio (GIR): This indicator measures the total number of new entrants in the first grade of primary education, regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the population at the official primary school-entrance age. Country-specific definition, method and targets are determined by countries themselves.

Name: Gender parity index for gross intake ratio in grade 1
Notes: Ratio of female to male values of gross intake ratio for primary first grade. Country-specific definition, method and targets are determined by countries themselves.

Name: Rate of out of school children, national source (% of relevant age group)
Notes: Number of children of official primary school age who are not enrolled in primary or secondary school, expressed as a percentage of the population of official primary school age. This indicator is intended to measure the size of the population in the official primary school age range that should be targeted by policies and efforts to achieve universal primary education. Country-specific definition, method and targets are determined by countries themselves.

Name: Primary completion rate, total, national source (% of relevant age group)
Notes: The Primary Completion Rate (PCR) is the percentage of pupils who completed the last year of primary schooling. It is computed by dividing the total number of students in the last grade of primary school minus repeaters in that grade, divided by the total number of children of official completing age. Country-specific definition, method and targets are determined by countries themselves.

Name: Gender parity index for primary completion rate
Notes: Ratio of female to male values of Primary Completion Rate. Country-specific definition, method and targets are determined by countries themselves.

Name: Progression to secondary school, national source (%)
Notes: This indicator measures the number of new entrants to the first grade of secondary education (general programs only) in a given year, expressed as a percentage of the number of pupils enrolled in the final grade of primary education in the previous year. Country-specific definition, method and targets are determined by countries themselves.

Name: Lower secondary completion rate, total, national source (% of relevant age group)
Notes: The lower secondary school completion rate is the percentage of children who are completing the last year of lower secondary education. It is computed by dividing the total number of students in the last grade of lower secondary education school minus repeaters in that grade divided by the total number of children of official completing age. Country-specific definition, method and targets are determined by countries themselves.

Name: Lower secondary education, new teachers, national source
Notes: Persons employed for the first time in an official capacity to guide and direct the learning experience of pupils in lower secondary school, excluding educational personnel who have no active teaching duties. Country-specific definition, method and targets are determined by countries themselves.

Name: Primary education, new entrants, national source
Notes: Pupils entering primary school for the first time, excluding repetears. Country-specific definition, method and targets are determined by countries themselves.

Name: Lower secondary education, classrooms, national source
Notes: Number of rooms or single accommodations, minimally equipped, in which a class of pupils in lower secondary school is taught. Country-specific definition, method and targets are determined by countries themselves.

Name: Lower secondary education, new classrooms, national source
Notes: Number of rooms or single accommodations, minimally equipped, built for the first time in which a class of pupils in lower secondary school is taught. Country-specific definition, method and targets are determined by countries themselves.

Name: Ratio of textbooks per pupil, primary education, mathematics
Notes: Number of books used by a single pupil used as a standard work for the study of the mathematics subject. Country-specific definition, method and targets are determined by countries themselves.

Name: Ratio of textbooks per pupil, primary education, language
Notes: Number of books used by a single pupil used as a standard work for the study of the primary language of instruction. Country-specific definition, method and targets are determined by countries themselves.

Name: Last study on effective learning time and teacher attendance (year)
Notes: Date (year) of the most recent study carried out by any national or international entity on the effectiveness of the instruction time devoted to learning activities.

Name: Primary education, pupils, national source
Notes: Total population of pupils in primary school, regardless of age. Country-specific definition, method and targets are determined by countries themselves.

Name: Primary education, teachers, national source
Notes: Persons employed in an official capacity to guide and direct the learning experience of pupils in primary school, excluding educational personnel who have no active teaching duties. Country-specific definition, method and targets are determined by countries themselves.

Name: Primary education, new teachers, national source
Notes: Persons employed for the first time in an official capacity to guide and direct the learning experience of pupils in primary school. Country-specific definition, method and targets are determined by countries themselves.

Name: Primary education, classrooms, national source
Notes: Number of rooms or single accommodations, minimally equipped, in which a class of pupils in primary school is taught. Country-specific definition, method and targets are determined by countries themselves.

Name: Primary education, new classrooms, national source
Notes: Number of rooms or single accommodations, minimally equipped, built for the first time in which a class of pupils in primary school is taught. Country-specific definition, method and targets are determined by countries themselves.

Name: Lower Secondary education, new entrants, national source
Notes: Pupils entering lower secondary school for the first time, excluding repeaters. Country-specific definition, method and targets are determined by countries themselves.

Name: Lower secondary education, pupils, national source
Notes: Total population of pupils in lower secondary school, regardless of age. Country-specific definition, method and targets are determined by countries themselves.

Name: Lower secondary education, teachers, national source
Notes: Persons employed in an official capacity to guide and direct the learning experience of pupils in lower secondary school, excluding educational personnel who have no active teaching duties. Country-specific definition, method and targets are determined by countries themselves.

Name: Public spending on total education (% of total public spending)
Notes: Public expenses devoted to the education sector, including recurrent and capital expenditures and teacher salaries, expressed as a percentage of the total general government expenses. Country-specific definition, method and targets are determined by countries themselves.

Name: Public spending on basic education (% of public spending on total education)
Notes: Public expenses devoted to the basic education sector, including recurrent and capital expenditures and teacher salaries, expressed as a percentage of the public spending on total education. Country-specific definition, method and targets are determined by countries themselves.

Name: Public recurrent spending on total education (% of total public recurrent spending)
Notes: Public recurrent expenses devoted to the education sector, expressed as a percentage of the total general government recurrent expenses. Country-specific definition, method and targets are determined by countries themselves.

Name: Public recurrent spending on basic education (% of public recurrent spending on total education)
Notes: Public recurrent expenses devoted to the basic education sector, expressed as a percentage of the public recurrent spending on total education. Country-specific definition, method and targets are determined by countries themselves.

Name: International aid disbursed to total education, CIDA to Afghanistan (USD million)
Notes: International concessional aid disbursed by the reporting development partner to the total education sector in the specific developing country. Targets indicate scheduled or projected aid. Accounted aid includes activities, projects, technical cooperation and sector and budget support (20%), as it was reported by the donor to the Global Partnership for Education.

Name: International aid disbursed to total education, World Bank to Albania (USD million)
Notes: International concessional aid disbursed by the reporting development partner to the total education sector in the specific developing country. Targets indicate scheduled or projected aid. Accounted aid includes activities, projects, technical cooperation and sector and budget support (20%), as it was reported by the donor to the Global Partnership for Education.

Notes: International concessional aid disbursed by the reporting development partner to the total education sector in the specific developing country. Targets indicate scheduled or projected aid. Notes: International concessional aid disbursed by the reporting development partner to the total education sector in the specific developing country. Targets indicate scheduled or projected aid. Notes: International concessional aid disbursed by the reporting development partner to the total education sector in the specific developing country. Targets indicate scheduled or projected aid. Notes: International concessional aid disbursed by the reporting development partner to the total education sector in the specific developing country. Targets indicate scheduled or projected aid. Name: International aid to total education executed by World Bank (including GPE funds) in Madagascar (USD million)
Notes: International concessional aid disbursed by the reporting development partner to the total education sector in the specific developing country. Targets indicate scheduled or projected aid. Accounted aid includes activities, projects, technical cooperation and sector and budget support (20%), as it was reported by the donor to the Global Partnership for Education.

Name: International aid disbursed to total education, Canada to Mozambique (USD million)
Notes: International concessional aid disbursed by the reporting development partner to the total education sector in the specific developing country. Targets indicate scheduled or projected aid. Accounted aid includes activities, projects, technical cooperation and sector and budget support (20%), as it was reported by the donor to the Global Partnership for Education.

Name: International aid disbursed to total education, AFD to Mauritania (USD million)
Notes: International concessional aid disbursed by the reporting development partner to the total education sector in the specific developing country. Targets indicate scheduled or projected aid. Accounted aid includes activities, projects, technical cooperation and sector and budget support (20%), as it was reported by the donor to the Global Partnership for Education.

Name: International aid disbursed to total education, AfDB to Malawi (USD million)
Notes: International concessional aid disbursed by the reporting development partner to the total education sector in the specific developing country. Targets indicate scheduled or projected aid. Accounted aid includes activities, projects, technical cooperation and sector and budget support (20%), as it was reported by the donor to the Global Partnership for Education.

Name: International aid disbursed to total education, AFD to Niger (USD million)
Notes: International concessional aid disbursed by the reporting development partner to the total education sector in the specific developing country. Targets indicate scheduled or projected aid. Accounted aid includes activities, projects, technical cooperation and sector and budget support (20%), as it was reported by the donor to the Global Partnership for Education.

Name: Access to electricity (% of total population)
Notes: Access to electricity is the percentage of population with access to electricity.

Name: Total final energy consumption (TFEC)
Notes: Total final energy consumption (TFEC): This indicator is derived form energy balances statistics and is equivalent to total final consumption excluding non-energy use.

Name: Access to electricity (% of rural population)
Notes: Access to electricity is the percentage of rural population with access to electricity.

Name: Access to electricity (% of urban population)
Notes: Access to electricity is the percentage of total population with access to electricity.

Name: Access to Clean Fuels and Technologies for cooking (% of total population)
Renewable energy consumption(% in TFEC)
Notes: Renewable energy consumption(% in TFEC): Share of renewables energy in total final energy consumption

Name: Renewable energy consumption (TJ)
Notes: Renewable energy consumption (TJ): This indicator includes renewable energy consumption of all technologies: hydro, modern and traditional biomass, wind, solar, liquid biofuels, biogas, geothermal, marine and waste

Name: Total electricity output (GWh)
Notes: Total electricity output (GWh): Total number of GWh generated by all power plants

Name: Renewable energy electricity output (GWh)
Notes: Renewable energy electricity output (GWh): Total number of GWh generated by renewable power plants, including wind, solar PV, solar thermal, hydro, marine, geothermal, biomass, renewable municipal waste, liquid biofuels and biogas. Electricity production for hydro pumpted storage is excluded.

Name: Renewable electricity (% in total electricity output)
Notes: Renewable electricity (% in total electricity output): Share of electrity generated by renewable power plants in total electricity generated by all types of plants

Name: Energy intensity level of primary energy (MJ/$2005 PPP)
Notes: Energy intensity level of primary energy (MJ/$2005 PPP): A ratio between energy supply and gross domestic product measured at purchasing power parity. Energy intensity is an indication of how much energy is used to produce one unit of economic output. Lower ratio indicates that less energy is used to produce one unit of output.

Name: Poverty Headcount ($1.90 a day)
Notes: The poverty headcount index measures the proportion of the population with daily per capita income (in 2011 PPP) below the poverty line.

Name: Poverty Headcount ($2.50 a day)
Notes: The poverty headcount index measures the proportion of the population with daily per capita income (in 2005 PPP) below the poverty line.

Name: Middle Class ($10-50 a day) Headcount
Notes: The poverty headcount index measures the proportion of the population with daily per capita income (in 2005 PPP) below the poverty line.

Name: Official Moderate Poverty Rate-National
Notes: The poverty headcount index measures the proportion of the population with daily per capita income below the official poverty line developed by each country.

Name: Poverty Headcount ($4 a day)
Notes: The poverty headcount index measures the proportion of the population with daily per capita income (in 2005 PPP) below the poverty line.

Name: Vulnerable ($4-10 a day) Headcount
Notes: The poverty headcount index measures the proportion of the population with daily per capita income (in 2005 PPP) below the poverty line.

Name: Poverty Gap ($1.90 a day)
Notes: The poverty gap captures the mean aggregate income or consumption shortfall relative to the poverty line across the entire population. It measures the total resources needed to bring all the poor to the level of the poverty line (averaged over the total population).

Name: Poverty Gap ($2.50 a day)
Notes: The poverty gap captures the mean aggregate income or consumption shortfall relative to the poverty line across the entire population. It measures the total resources needed to bring all the poor to the level of the poverty line (averaged over the total population).

Name: Poverty Gap ($4 a day)
Notes: The poverty gap captures the mean aggregate income or consumption shortfall relative to the poverty line across the entire population. It measures the total resources needed to bring all the poor to the level of the poverty line (averaged over the total population).

Name: Poverty Severity ($1.90 a day)
Notes: The poverty severity index combines information on both poverty and inequality among the poor by averaging the squares of the poverty gaps relative the poverty line

Name: Poverty Severity ($2.50 a day)
Notes: The poverty severity index combines information on both poverty and inequality among the poor by averaging the squares of the poverty gaps relative the poverty line

Name: Poverty Severity ($4 a day)
Notes: The poverty severity index combines information on both poverty and inequality among the poor by averaging the squares of the poverty gaps relative the poverty line

Name: Poverty headcount ratio at national poverty lines (% of population)
Notes: National poverty headcount ratio is the percentage of the population living below the national poverty line(s). National estimates are based on population-weighted subgroup estimates from household surveys. For economies for which the data are from EU-SILC, the reported year is the income reference year, which is the year before the survey year.

Name: Rural poverty headcount ratio at national poverty lines (% of rural population)
Notes: Rural poverty headcount ratio is the percentage of the rural population living below the national poverty lines.

Name: Urban poverty headcount ratio at national poverty lines (% of urban population)
Notes: Urban poverty headcount ratio is the percentage of the urban population living below the national poverty lines.

Name: Problems in accessing health care (not wanting to go alone) (% of women): Q1 (lowest)
Notes: Problems in accessing health care: Percentage of women who report they have big problems in accessing health care for themselves when they are sick, by type of problem. The types of problem specified are; knowing where to go for treatment, getting permission to go for treatment, getting money for treatment, distance to health facility, having to take transport, not wanting to go alone, and concern there may not be a female provider.

Name: Problems in accessing health care (knowing where to go for treatment) (% of women): Q5 (highest)
Notes: Problems in accessing health care: Percentage of women who report they have big problems in accessing health care for themselves when they are sick, by type of problem. The types of problem specified are; knowing where to go for treatment, getting permission to go for treatment, getting money for treatment, distance to health facility, having to take transport, not wanting to go alone, and concern there may not be a female provider.

Name: Under-5 mortality rate (per 1,000 live births): Q1 (lowest)
Notes: Under-5 mortality rate: Number of deaths to children under age five years per 1000 live births, based on experience during the reference period before the survey. The reference period is ten years preceding the survey for DHS surveys, and the reference period varies for MICS surveys (often three to five years preceding the survey).

Name: Under-5 mortality rate (per 1,000 live births): Q2
Notes: Under-5 mortality rate: Number of deaths to children under age five years per 1000 live births, based on experience during the reference period before the survey. The reference period is ten years preceding the survey for DHS surveys, and the reference period varies for MICS surveys (often three to five years preceding the survey).

Name: Under-5 mortality rate (per 1,000 live births): Q3
Notes: Under-5 mortality rate: Number of deaths to children under age five years per 1000 live births, based on experience during the reference period before the survey. The reference period is ten years preceding the survey for DHS surveys, and the reference period varies for MICS surveys (often three to five years preceding the survey).

Name: Under-5 mortality rate (per 1,000 live births): Q4
Notes: Under-5 mortality rate: Number of deaths to children under age five years per 1000 live births, based on experience during the reference period before the survey. The reference period is ten years preceding the survey for DHS surveys, and the reference period varies for MICS surveys (often three to five years preceding the survey).

Name: Under-5 mortality rate (per 1,000 live births): Q5 (highest)
Notes: Under-5 mortality rate: Number of deaths to children under age five years per 1000 live births, based on experience during the reference period before the survey. The reference period is ten years preceding the survey for DHS surveys, and the reference period varies for MICS surveys (often three to five years preceding the survey).

Name: Acceptability of media messages on family planning (% of women): Q1 (lowest)
Notes: Acceptability of media messages on family planning: Percentage of all women who believe that it is acceptable to have messages about family planning on the radio or television.

Name: Acceptability of media messages on family planning (% of women): Q2
Notes: Acceptability of media messages on family planning: Percentage of all women who believe that it is acceptable to have messages about family planning on the radio or television.

Name: Acceptability of media messages on family planning (% of women): Q3
Notes: Acceptability of media messages on family planning: Percentage of all women who believe that it is acceptable to have messages about family planning on the radio or television.

Name: Acceptability of media messages on family planning (% of women): Q4
Notes: Acceptability of media messages on family planning: Percentage of all women who believe that it is acceptable to have messages about family planning on the radio or television.

Name: Acceptability of media messages on family planning (% of women): Q5 (highest)
Notes: Acceptability of media messages on family planning: Percentage of all women who believe that it is acceptable to have messages about family planning on the radio or television.

Name: Number of deaths ages 5-9 years
Notes: Number of deaths of children ages 5-9 years

Name: Number of deaths ages 5-14 years
Notes: Number of deaths of children ages 5-14 years

Name: Number of deaths ages 10-14 years
Notes: Number of deaths of adolescents ages 10-14 years

Name: Number of deaths ages 10-19 years
Notes: Number of deaths of adolescents ages 10-19 years

Name: Number of deaths ages 15-19 years
Notes: Number of deaths of adolescents ages 15-19 years

Name: Number of deaths ages 20-24 years
Notes: Number of deaths of youths ages 20-24 years

Name: Number of infant deaths
Notes: Number of infants dying before reaching one year of age.

Name: Number of infant deaths, female
Notes: Number of female infants dying before reaching one year of age.

Name: Number of infant deaths, male
Notes: Number of male infants dying before reaching one year of age.

Name: Number of under-five deaths
Notes: Number of children dying before reaching age five.

Name: Number of under-five deaths, female
Notes: Number of female children dying before reaching age five.

Name: Number of under-five deaths, male
Notes: Number of male children dying before reaching age five.

Name: Number of neonatal deaths
Notes: Number of neonates dying before reaching 28 days of age.

Name: Probability of dying among children ages 5-9 years (per 1,000)
Notes: Probability of dying between age 5-9 years of age expressed per 1,000 children aged 5, if subject to age-specific mortality rates of the specified year.

Name: Probability of dying at age 5-14 years (per 1,000 children age 5)
Notes: Probability of dying between age 5-14 years of age expressed per 1,000 children aged 5, if subject to age-specific mortality rates of the specified year.

Name: Probability of dying among adolescents ages 10-14 years (per 1,000)
Notes: Probability of dying between age 10-14 years of age expressed per 1,000 adolescents age 10, if subject to age-specific mortality rates of the specified year.

Name: Probability of dying among adolescents ages 10-19 years (per 1,000)
Notes: Probability of dying between age 10-19 years of age expressed per 1,000 adolescents age 10, if subject to age-specific mortality rates of the specified year.

Name: Probability of dying among adolescents ages 15-19 years (per 1,000)
Notes: Probability of dying between age 15-19 years of age expressed per 1,000 adolescents age 15, if subject to age-specific mortality rates of the specified year.

Name: Probability of dying among youth ages 20-24 years (per 1,000)
Notes: Probability of dying between age 20-24 years of age expressed per 1,000 youths age 20, if subject to age-specific mortality rates of the specified year.

Name: Mortality rate, under-5 (per 1,000 live births)
Notes: Under-five mortality rate is the probability per 1,000 that a newborn baby will die before reaching age five, if subject to age-specific mortality rates of the specified year.

Name: Mortality rate, under-5, female (per 1,000 live births)
Notes: Under-five mortality rate, female is the probability per 1,000 that a newborn female baby will die before reaching age five, if subject to female age-specific mortality rates of the specified year.

Name: Mortality rate, under-5, male (per 1,000 live births)
Notes: Under-five mortality rate, male is the probability per 1,000 that a newborn male baby will die before reaching age five, if subject to male age-specific mortality rates of the specified year.

Name: Mortality rate, neonatal (per 1,000 live births)
Notes: Neonatal mortality rate is the number of neonates dying before reaching 28 days of age, per 1,000 live births in a given year.

Name: Net migration
Notes: Net migration is the net total of migrants during the period, that is, the number of immigrants minus the number of emigrants, including both citizens and noncitizens.

Name: Mortality rate, adult, female (per 1,000 female adults)
Notes: Adult mortality rate, female, is the probability of dying between the ages of 15 and 60--that is, the probability of a 15-year-old female dying before reaching age 60, if subject to age-specific mortality rates of the specified year between those ages.

Name: Mortality rate, adult, male (per 1,000 male adults)
Notes: Adult mortality rate, male, is the probability of dying between the ages of 15 and 60--that is, the probability of a 15-year-old male dying before reaching age 60, if subject to age-specific mortality rates of the specified year between those ages.

Name: Birth rate, crude (per 1,000 people)
Notes: Crude birth rate indicates the number of live births occurring during the year, per 1,000 population estimated at midyear. Subtracting the crude death rate from the crude birth rate provides the rate of natural increase, which is equal to the rate of population change in the absence of migration.

Name: Death rate, crude (per 1,000 people)
Notes: Crude death rate indicates the number of deaths occurring during the year, per 1,000 population estimated at midyear. Subtracting the crude death rate from the crude birth rate provides the rate of natural increase, which is equal to the rate of population change in the absence of migration.

Name: Mortality rate, infant, female (per 1,000 live births)
Notes: Infant mortality rate, female is the number of female infants dying before reaching one year of age, per 1,000 female live births in a given year.

Name: Mortality rate, infant (per 1,000 live births)
Notes: Infant mortality rate is the number of infants dying before reaching one year of age, per 1,000 live births in a given year.

Name: Mortality rate, infant, male (per 1,000 live births)
Notes: Infant mortality rate, male is the number of male infants dying before reaching one year of age, per 1,000 male live births in a given year.

Name: Life expectancy at birth, female (years)
Notes: Life expectancy at birth indicates the number of years a newborn infant would live if prevailing patterns of mortality at the time of its birth were to stay the same throughout its life.

Name: Life expectancy at birth, total (years)
Notes: Life expectancy at birth indicates the number of years a newborn infant would live if prevailing patterns of mortality at the time of its birth were to stay the same throughout its life.

Name: Life expectancy at birth, male (years)
Notes: Life expectancy at birth indicates the number of years a newborn infant would live if prevailing patterns of mortality at the time of its birth were to stay the same throughout its life.

Name: Fertility rate, total (births per woman)
Notes: Total fertility rate represents the number of children that would be born to a woman if she were to live to the end of her childbearing years and bear children in accordance with age-specific fertility rates of the specified year.

Name: Population ages 00-04, female
Notes: Female population between the ages 0 to 4.

Name: Population ages 00-04, female (% of female population)
Notes: Female population between the ages 0 to 4 as a percentage of the total female population.

Name: Population ages 00-04, male
Notes: Male population between the ages 0 to 4.

Name: Population ages 00-04, male (% of male population)
Notes: Male population between the ages 0 to 4 as a percentage of the total male population.

Name: Population ages 0-14, female
Notes: Female population between the ages 0 to 14. Population is based on the de facto definition of population, which counts all residents regardless of legal status or citizenship.

Name: Population ages 0-14, female (% of female population)
Notes: Female population between the ages 0 to 14 as a percentage of the total female population. Population is based on the de facto definition of population.

Name: Population ages 0-14, male
Notes: Male population between the ages 0 to 14. Population is based on the de facto definition of population, which counts all residents regardless of legal status or citizenship.

Name: Population ages 0-14, male (% of male population)
Notes: Male population between the ages 0 to 14 as a percentage of the total male population. Population is based on the de facto definition of population.

Name: Population ages 0-14, total
Notes: Total population between the ages 0 to 14. Population is based on the de facto definition of population, which counts all residents regardless of legal status or citizenship.

Name: Population ages 0-14 (% of total population)
Notes: Population between the ages 0 to 14 as a percentage of the total population. Population is based on the de facto definition of population.

Name: Population ages 05-09, female
Notes: Female population between the ages 5 to 9.

Name: Population ages 05-09, female (% of female population)
Notes: Female population between the ages 5 to 9 as a percentage of the total female population.

Name: Population ages 05-09, male
Notes: Male population between the ages 5 to 9.

Name: Population ages 05-09, male (% of male population)
Notes: Male population between the ages 5 to 9 as a percentage of the total male population.

Name: Population ages 10-14, female
Notes: Female population between the ages 10 to 14.

Name: Gross Irrigated Area under all crops ('000 hectares)
Notes: Gross area under irrigation is the total area under crops, irrigated once and/or more than once in a year. It is counted as many times as the number of times the areas are cropped and irrigated in a year.

Name: Yield - All Foodgrains (Kgs/Hectare)
Notes: Yield of Total Foodgrains (Rice, Wheat, etc.), measured in Kgs/Hectare, is derived by aggregating the individual foodgrain production (Kgs) and total harvested areas (hectares), which are estimated using their Yield.

Name: Yield - Rice (Kgs/Hectare)
Notes: Yield of Rice, measured in Kgs/Hectare, is an estimate based on randomized sampling of survey areas and controlled crop cutting experiments.

Name: Yield - Sugarcane (Kgs/Hectare)
Notes: Yield of Sugarcane, measured in Kgs/Hectare, is an estimate based on randomized sampling of survey areas and controlled crop cutting experiments.

Name: Nominal GSDP Per Capita (INR)
Notes:
Nominal Gross state domestic product (GSDP) per capita, or gross regional product (GRP) per capita, is a measurement of the per capita economic output in nominal terms of a state or province (i.e., of a subnational entity). It is the sum of all value added by industries and services within the state and serves as a counterpart to the gross domestic product (GDP). 
State Domestic Product (SDP) in common parlance known as “State Income” is a measure in monetary terms of the volume of all goods and services produced during a given period of time within the geographical boundaries of the state, accounted for
without duplication.

Name: Nominal GSDP Per Capita (USD)
Notes:
Nominal Gross state domestic product (GSDP) per capita, or gross regional product (GRP) per capita, is a measurement of the per capita economic output in nominal terms of a state or province (i.e., of a subnational entity). It is the sum of all value added by industries and services within the state and serves as a counterpart to the gross domestic product (GDP). 
State Domestic Product (SDP) in common parlance known as “State Income” is a measure in monetary terms of the volume of all goods and services produced during a given period of time within the geographical boundaries of the state, accounted for
without duplication.

Name: Real GSDP Per Capita (INR)
Notes:
Real Gross state domestic product (GSDP), or gross regional product (GRP), is a measurement of the per capita economic output in real terms of a state or province (i.e., of a subnational entity). It is the sum of all value added by industries and services within the state and serves as a counterpart to the gross domestic product (GDP). 
State Domestic Product (SDP) in common parlance known as “State Income” is a measure in monetary terms of the volume of all goods and services produced during a given period of time within the geographical boundaries of the state, accounted for
without duplication.

Name: Real GSDP Per Capita (INR) Growth Rate
Notes:
Real Gross state domestic product (GSDP) [per capita, or gross regional product (GRP) per capita, is a measurement of the per capita growth rate of economic output in real terms of a state or province (i.e., of a subnational entity). It is the sum of all value added by industries and services within the state and serves as a counterpart to the gross domestic product (GDP). 
State Domestic Product (SDP) in common parlance known as “State Income” is a measure in monetary terms of the volume of all goods and services produced during a given period of time within the geographical boundaries of the state, accounted for
without duplication.

Name: Real GSDP Per Capita (USD)
Notes:
Real Gross state domestic product (GSDP) per capita, or gross regional product (GRP) per capita, is a measurement of the per capita economic output in real terms of a state or province (i.e., of a subnational entity). It is the sum of all value added by industries and services within the state and serves as a counterpart to the gross domestic product (GDP). 
State Domestic Product (SDP) in common parlance known as “State Income” is a measure in monetary terms of the volume of all goods and services produced during a given period of time within the geographical boundaries of the state, accounted for
without duplication.

Name: Real GSDP Per Capita (USD) Growth Rate
Notes:
Gross state domestic product (GSDP), or gross regional product (GRP), is a measurement of the per capita growth rate  of the economic output in real terms of a state or province (i.e., of a subnational entity). It is the sum of all value added by industries and services within the state and serves as a counterpart to the gross domestic product (GDP). 
State Domestic Product (SDP) in common parlance known as “State Income” is a measure in monetary terms of the volume of all goods and services produced during a given period of time within the geographical boundaries of the state, accounted for
without duplication.

Name: Decadal Growth of Population (%)
Notes: Population growth rate over the 10 year period.  This is simple growth rate calculation between two population observations that are 10 year apart.

Name: Decadal Growth of Population, Rural (%)
Decadal Growth of Population, Urban (%)
Population, Rural (Thousands)
Population, Rural (%)

Population, Urban (%)
Enrolment by Caste-General (%)
Notes: Percent pupils in General category: not belonging to the Scheduled Caste (SC), Scheduled Tribe (ST) or Other Backward Class (OBC) category. Muslims and other minorities are included in the General Category.

Name: Enrolment by Caste-Muslim (%)
Notes: Percent of Secondary and Higher Secondary pupils in the General category and belonging to the Muslim community

Name: Enrolment by Caste-OBC (%)
Notes: Percent pupils not in the General category and belonging to the Other Backward Class (OBC) category

Name: Enrolment by Caste-SC (%)
Notes: Percent pupils not in the General category and belonging to the Scheduled Caste (SC) category

Name: Enrolment by Caste-ST (%)
Notes: Percent pupils not in the General category and belonging to the Scheduled Tribe (ST) category

Name: Gross Enrolment Ratio (%)
Notes: Total enrolment in secondary and higher secondary education, regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the eligible official secondary and higher secondary school-age population in a given school-year

Name: Net Enrolment Ratio (%)
Notes: Enrolment in secondary and higher secondary education of the official age for that group expressed as a percentage of the corresponding population in that age group

Name: Pupil-Teacher Ratio
Notes: Average number of Pupils per Teacher for all schools (Secondary and Higher Secondary schools).

Name: Teachers (Number)
Notes: Total number of Teachers in secondary and higher secondary schools. Thes include regular and on-contract teachers.

Name: Teacher Education Institutes (DIETs, CTEs, IASEs)
Notes: Numbers of Teacher Education Institutes sponsored and funded by the Central Government for elementary and secondary schools-- District Institutes of Education and Trainin(DIETs), Colleges of Teacher Education (CTEs),  Institutes of Advanced Study in Education (IASEs)

Name: Total- Installed Capacity (MW)
Notes: Total- Installed Capacity (MW). Includes hydro, diesel and wind, steam, gas and nuclear energy.

Name: Total-Electricity Generated Gross (GWh)
Notes: Total-Electricity Generated Gross (GWh). Includes hydro, diesel and wind, steam, gas and nuclear energy.

Name: Utilities/Non Utilities Per Capita Consumption (KWh)
Notes: Utilities/Non Utilities  Per Capita Consumption (in KWh).  Uses net electricity consumption after excluding  consumption by power station auxiliaries. Non-utilities are power stations for railways and similar entities.

Name: Non Utilities Per Capita Consumption (KWh)
Notes: Non Utilities  Per Capita Consumption (in KWh)

Name: Total (Utilities & Non-Utilities) Per Capita Consumption (KWh)
Notes: Total (Utilities & Non-Utilities) Per Capita Consumption (in KWh). Uses net electricity consumption after excluding  consumption by power station auxiliaries. Non-utilities are power stations for railways and similar entities.

Name: Grid interactive renewable power installed capacity (MW)
Notes: Grid interactive renewable power installed capacity (in MW). Includes power generated from small hydro, biomass and waste, wind and solar sources. Energy from these renewable sources is connected to the regional and state grids.

Name: Number of Towns Electrified (Per 2001 Census)
Notes: Number of Towns Electrified (Per 2001 Census)

Name: Number of Towns Electrified (Percentage)
Notes: Percentage of Towns in the State Electrified

Notes: Number of Towns Total (Per 2001 Census)

Notes: Number of Villages Electrified

Notes: Percentage of Villages Electrified in the State

Notes: Number of Villages Total (Per 2001 Census)

Adjusted savings: education expenditure (current US$)
Notes: Education expenditure refers to the current operating expenditures in education, including wages and salaries and excluding capital investments in buildings and equipment.

Name: Adjusted savings: education expenditure (% of GNI)
Notes: Education expenditure refers to the current operating expenditures in education, including wages and salaries and excluding capital investments in buildings and equipment.

Name: Adjusted savings: carbon dioxide damage (current US$)
Notes: Cost of damage due to carbon dioxide emissions from fossil fuel use and the manufacture of cement, estimated to be US$40 per ton of CO2 (the unit damage in 2017 US dollars for CO2 emitted in 2020) times the number of tons of CO2 emitted.

Name: Adjusted savings: carbon dioxide damage (% of GNI)
Notes: Cost of damage due to carbon dioxide emissions from fossil fuel use and the manufacture of cement, estimated to be US$40 per ton of CO2 (the unit damage in 2017 US dollars for CO2 emitted in 2020) times the number of tons of CO2 emitted.

Name: Adjusted savings: net forest depletion (current US$)
Notes: Net forest depletion is calculated as the product of unit resource rents and the excess of roundwood harvest over natural growth.

Name: Adjusted savings: net forest depletion (% of GNI)
Notes: Net forest depletion is calculated as the product of unit resource rents and the excess of roundwood harvest over natural growth.

Name: Adjusted savings: consumption of fixed capital (current US$)
Notes: Consumption of fixed capital represents the replacement value of capital used up in the process of production.

Name: Adjusted savings: consumption of fixed capital (% of GNI)
Notes: Consumption of fixed capital represents the replacement value of capital used up in the process of production.

Name: Adjusted savings: mineral depletion (current US$)
Notes: Mineral depletion is the ratio of the value of the stock of mineral resources to the remaining reserve lifetime (capped at 25 years). It covers tin, gold, lead, zinc, iron, copper, nickel, silver, bauxite, and phosphate.

Name: Adjusted savings: mineral depletion (% of GNI)
Notes: Mineral depletion is the ratio of the value of the stock of mineral resources to the remaining reserve lifetime (capped at 25 years). It covers tin, gold, lead, zinc, iron, copper, nickel, silver, bauxite, and phosphate.

Name: Adjusted savings: energy depletion (current US$)
Notes: Energy depletion is the ratio of the value of the stock of energy resources to the remaining reserve lifetime (capped at 25 years). It covers coal, crude oil, and natural gas.

Name: Adjusted savings: energy depletion (% of GNI)
Notes: Energy depletion is the ratio of the value of the stock of energy resources to the remaining reserve lifetime (capped at 25 years). It covers coal, crude oil, and natural gas.

Name: Adjusted savings: particulate emission damage (current US$)
Notes: Particulate emissions damage is the damage due to exposure of a country's population to ambient concentrations of particulates measuring less than 2.5 microns in diameter (PM2.5), ambient ozone pollution, and indoor concentrations of PM2.5 in households cooking with solid fuels. Damages are calculated as foregone labor income due to premature death. Estimates of health impacts from the Global Burden of Disease Study 2013 are for 1990, 1995, 2000, 2005, 2010, and 2013. Data for other years have been extrapolated from trends in mortality rates.

Name: Adjusted savings: particulate emission damage (% of GNI)
Notes: Particulate emissions damage is the damage due to exposure of a country's population to ambient concentrations of particulates measuring less than 2.5 microns in diameter (PM2.5), ambient ozone pollution, and indoor concentrations of PM2.5 in households cooking with solid fuels. Damages are calculated as foregone labor income due to premature death. Estimates of health impacts from the Global Burden of Disease Study 2013 are for 1990, 1995, 2000, 2005, 2010, and 2013. Data for other years have been extrapolated from trends in mortality rates.

Name: Adjusted savings: natural resources depletion (% of GNI)
Notes: Natural resource depletion is the sum of net forest depletion, energy depletion, and mineral depletion. Net forest depletion is unit resource rents times the excess of roundwood harvest over natural growth. Energy depletion is the ratio of the value of the stock of energy resources to the remaining reserve lifetime (capped at 25 years). It covers coal, crude oil, and natural gas. Mineral depletion is the ratio of the value of the stock of mineral resources to the remaining reserve lifetime (capped at 25 years). It covers tin, gold, lead, zinc, iron, copper, nickel, silver, bauxite, and phosphate.

Name: Adjusted savings: gross savings (current US$)
Notes: Gross savings are the difference between gross national income and public and private consumption, plus net current transfers.

Name: Adjusted savings: gross savings (% of GNI)
Notes: Gross savings are the difference between gross national income and public and private consumption, plus net current transfers.

Name: Adjusted savings: net national savings (current US$)
Notes: Net national savings are equal to gross national savings less the value of consumption of fixed capital.

Name: Adjusted savings: net national savings (% of GNI)
Notes: Net national savings are equal to gross national savings less the value of consumption of fixed capital.

Name: Adjusted net national income (current US$)
Notes: Adjusted net national income is GNI minus consumption of fixed capital and natural resources depletion.

Name: Adjusted net national income (constant 2015 US$)
Notes: Adjusted net national income is GNI minus consumption of fixed capital and natural resources depletion.

Name: Adjusted net national income (annual % growth)
Notes: Adjusted net national income is GNI minus consumption of fixed capital and natural resources depletion.

Name: Adjusted net national income per capita (current US$)
Notes: Adjusted net national income is GNI minus consumption of fixed capital and natural resources depletion.

Name: Adjusted net national income per capita (constant 2015 US$)
Notes: Adjusted net national income is GNI minus consumption of fixed capital and natural resources depletion.

Name: Adjusted net national income per capita (annual % growth)
Notes: Adjusted net national income is GNI minus consumption of fixed capital and natural resources depletion.

Name: Adjusted net savings, including particulate emission damage (current US$)
Notes: Adjusted net savings are equal to net national savings plus education expenditure and minus energy depletion, mineral depletion, net forest depletion, and carbon dioxide and particulate emissions damage.

Name: Adjusted net savings, including particulate emission damage (% of GNI)
Notes: Adjusted net savings are equal to net national savings plus education expenditure and minus energy depletion, mineral depletion, net forest depletion, and carbon dioxide and particulate emissions damage.

Name: Adjusted net savings per capita (current US$)
Notes: Adjusted net savings are equal to net national savings plus education expenditure and minus energy depletion, mineral depletion, net forest depletion, and carbon dioxide and particulate emissions damage.

Name: Adjusted net savings, excluding particulate emission damage (current US$)
Notes: Adjusted net savings are equal to net national savings plus education expenditure and minus energy depletion, mineral depletion, net forest depletion, and carbon dioxide. This series excludes particulate emissions damage.

Name: Adjusted net savings, excluding particulate emission damage (% of GNI)
Notes: Adjusted net savings are equal to net national savings plus education expenditure and minus energy depletion, mineral depletion, net forest depletion, and carbon dioxide. This series excludes particulate emissions damage.

Name: Coal rents (% of GDP)
Notes: Coal rents are the difference between the value of both hard and soft coal production at world prices and their total costs of production.

Name: Forest rents (% of GDP)
Notes: Forest rents are roundwood harvest times the product of regional prices and a regional rental rate.

Name: Mineral rents (% of GDP)
Notes: Mineral rents are the difference between the value of production for a stock of minerals at world prices and their total costs of production. Minerals included in the calculation are tin, gold, lead, zinc, iron, copper, nickel, silver, bauxite, and phosphate.

Name: Natural gas rents (% of GDP)
Notes: Natural gas rents are the difference between the value of natural gas production at regional prices and total costs of production.

Name: Oil rents (% of GDP)
Notes: Oil rents are the difference between the value of crude oil production at regional prices and total costs of production.

Name: Total natural resources rents (% of GDP)
Notes: Total natural resources rents are the sum of oil rents, natural gas rents, coal rents (hard and soft), mineral rents, and forest rents.

Name: BPK Audit Report on Sub-National Budget
Total Specific Allocation Grant for Agriculture (in IDR Billion)
Notes: The Specific Allocation Grant (DAK) is a fund sourced from revenue in the Central Budget (APBN) allocated to a certain region with the aim of funding special activities of the region in accordance with national priorities. The DAK allocation has a formula component that takes into account the fiscal gap and has a 10 percent matching requirement. The DAK is earmarked for capital spending and cannot be used for research, training, administration, or official travel.

Name: Total Specific Allocation Grant for Education (in IDR Billion)
Notes: The Specific Allocation Grant (DAK) is a fund sourced from revenue in the Central Budget (APBN) allocated to a certain region with the aim of funding special activities of the region in accordance with national priorities. The DAK allocation has a formula component that takes into account the fiscal gap and has a 10 percent matching requirement. The DAK is earmarked for capital spending and cannot be used for research, training, administration, or official travel.

Name: Total Specific Allocation Grant for Environment (in IDR Billion)
Notes: The Specific Allocation Grant (DAK) is a fund sourced from revenue in the Central Budget (APBN) allocated to a certain region with the aim of funding special activities of the region in accordance with national priorities. The DAK allocation has a formula component that takes into account the fiscal gap and has a 10 percent matching requirement. The DAK is earmarked for capital spending and cannot be used for research, training, administration, or official travel.

Name: Total Specific Allocation Grant for Forestry (in IDR Billion)
Notes: The Specific Allocation Grant (DAK) is a fund sourced from revenue in the Central Budget (APBN) allocated to a certain region with the aim of funding special activities of the region in accordance with national priorities. The DAK allocation has a formula component that takes into account the fiscal gap and has a 10 percent matching requirement. The DAK is earmarked for capital spending and cannot be used for research, training, administration, or official travel.

Name: Total Specific Allocation Grant for Fishery (in IDR Billion)
Notes: The Specific Allocation Grant (DAK) is a fund sourced from revenue in the Central Budget (APBN) allocated to a certain region with the aim of funding special activities of the region in accordance with national priorities. The DAK allocation has a formula component that takes into account the fiscal gap and has a 10 percent matching requirement. The DAK is earmarked for capital spending and cannot be used for research, training, administration, or official travel.

Name: Total Specific Allocation Grant for Government Sector (in IDR Billion)
Notes: The Specific Allocation Grant (DAK) is a fund sourced from revenue in the Central Budget (APBN) allocated to a certain region with the aim of funding special activities of the region in accordance with national priorities. The DAK allocation has a formula component that takes into account the fiscal gap and has a 10 percent matching requirement. The DAK is earmarked for capital spending and cannot be used for research, training, administration, or official travel.

Name: Total Specific Allocation Grant for Health Sector (Subsect: Basic Services) (in IDR Billion)
Notes: The Specific Allocation Grant (DAK) is a fund sourced from revenue in the Central Budget (APBN) allocated to a certain region with the aim of funding special activities of the region in accordance with national priorities. The DAK allocation has a formula component that takes into account the fiscal gap and has a 10 percent matching requirement. The DAK is earmarked for capital spending and cannot be used for research, training, administration, or official travel.

The DAK allocation has a formula component that takes into account the fiscal gap and has a 10 percent matching requirement. The DAK is earmarked for capital spending and cannot be used for research, training, administration, or official travel.

Notes: The Specific Allocation Grant (DAK) is a fund sourced from revenue in the Central Budget (APBN) allocated to a certain region with the aim of funding special activities of the region in accordance with national priorities. The DAK is earmarked for capital spending and cannot be used for research, training, administration, or official travel.

The DAK allocation has a formula component that takes into account the fiscal gap and has a 10 percent matching requirement.
